key_insight: MAI-UI introduces a family of foundation GUI agents across model scales (2B → 235B-A22B) and a deployment‑oriented design that closes the gap between research prototypes and real‑world GUI agent usage, prioritizing native user interaction and robustness.
problem_solved: Addresses four practical barriers to realistic GUI agent deployment: lack of native agent–user interaction, the limitations of UI‑only operation, absence of a practical deployment architecture, and brittleness in dynamic real‑world environments.
method: Provide a spectrum of foundation GUI agent sizes (2B, 8B, 32B, 235B‑A22B) to match different compute and capability tradeoffs.
Design for real‑world centricity: enable native agent–user interaction and extend beyond UI‑only control (multi‑modal inputs/outputs and environment awareness).
Propose a practical deployment architecture plus robustness mechanisms (monitoring, adaptation, and environment‑aware strategies) to reduce brittleness in dynamic settings.
impact: Enables AI/ML practitioners to choose appropriately sized GUI agents and deploy them in production with improved interaction fidelity and resilience, accelerating real‑world HCI applications and reducing integration friction.
visual_elements: Architecture diagram showing agent stack + deployment components (client UI, agent core, monitoring/adaptation layer, backend services).
Scalability chart mapping model sizes (2B→235B‑A22B) to latency, capability, and recommended use cases.
Interaction flow illustrating native agent–user dialogues and multi‑modal inputs/outputs across a GUI.
Robustness matrix or timeline visualizing failure modes and mitigation strategies in dynamic environments.
paper_title: MAI-UI Technical Report: Real-World Centric Foundation GUI Agents
paper_authors: Hanzhang Zhou, Xu Zhang, Panrong Tong, Jianan Zhang, Liangyu Chen
